for purposes referred to in subsection (1) (b) (ii), have the effect of reducing the portion of the allowable annual cut then approved for the tree farm licence area that the chief forester determines is attributable to the Crown land to which subsection (1) (b) applies by more than 5% of the portion of the allowable annual cut for the tree farm licence that the chief forester determines was attributable to that land at the beginning of the deletion period, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: from a woodlot licence area under subsection (1) (c),

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: for purposes referred to in subsection (1) (c) (i), have the effect of reducing the allowable annual cut approved for the woodlot licence by more than 5% of the allowable annual cut approved at the beginning of the deletion period, or

for purposes under subsection (1) (c) (ii), have the effect of reducing the allowable annual cut approved for the woodlot licence by more than 5% of the allowable annual cut approved at the beginning of the deletion period,

section.subsandwich: the government must compensate its holder in respect of the amount of the reduction exceeding 5%, for the unexpired portion of its term.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the total deletions made under subsection (1) (c) during a deletion period from the area described in a timber licence

paragraph.paragraphtext: for purposes referred to in subsection (1) (c) (i) exceed 5% of the area described in the timber licence at the beginning of the deletion period, or
for purposes under subsection (1) (c) (ii) exceed 5% of the area described in the timber licence at the beginning of the deletion period,

section.subsandwich: the government must compensate its holder in respect of the area exceeding 5%.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the total reductions in the allowable annual cut authorized in a forest licence made during a deletion period, in consequence of Crown land use

paragraph.paragraphtext: for purposes referred to in subsection (1) (d) (i) exceed 5% of the allowable annual cut authorized for the licence at the beginning of the deletion period, or
for purposes under subsection (1) (d) (ii) exceed 5% of the allowable annual cut authorized for the licence at the beginning of the deletion period,

section.subsandwich: the government must compensate its holder in respect of the amount of the reduction exceeding 5%, for the unexpired portion of its term.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to compensation otherwise payable under this section, the government must compensate the holder of a tree farm licence, woodlot licence, timber licence, forest licence or timber sale licence for improvements made to Crown land that

paragraph.paragraphtext: are authorized by the government, and
are not paid for by the government under this or the former Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (5) does not apply in respect of basic silviculture carried out by the holder of a licence.
If the amount of compensation is not agreed on, it must be submitted for determination by one arbitrator or 3 arbitrators appointed under the Commercial Arbitration Act and

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person who is to be compensated must elect, in a notice served on the minister, whether one or three arbitrators are to be appointed, and
the Commercial Arbitration Act applies to the submission.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the consent of the person entitled, compensation payable under subsection (2), (3) or (4) may take the form of an agreement listed in section 12, other than a timber sale licence.

A tree farm licence, woodlot licence, timber licence, forest licence or timber sale licence is deemed to be amended to the extent provided in a notice served under subsection (1), and the district manager or timber sales manager must serve the holder with a notice, evidencing the amendment.

change.changenote: Sections 60 to 60.95 BEFORE repealed by 2021-38-34, effective July 15, 2023 (BC Reg 153/2023).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Deletions, not affecting allowable annual cut, of Crown land from tree farm licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, Crown land does not include Crown land described in a timber licence.
The minister by written order may delete Crown land from a tree farm licence area, if the deletion does not affect the allowable annual cut determined for the tree farm licence.
Subject to section 60.92, no compensation or damages is payable by the government to a person for a deletion of Crown land under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other deletions, not affecting allowable annual cut, of Crown land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister by written order may delete Crown land from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community forest agreement area,
a first nations woodland licence area, or
a woodlot licence area

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if the deletion does not affect the allowable annual cut determined for the community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence.
Subject to section 60.92, no compensation or damages is payable by the government to a person for a deletion of Crown land under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this section and in sections 60.2 to 60.91:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: for an access purpose means for the purpose of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: access to Crown timber,
a right of way for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a highway,
a pipeline, or
power transmission, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: water storage;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: for another purpose means for any purpose other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an access purpose, or
timber production.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other deletions of Crown land — tree farm licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, Crown land does not include Crown land described in a timber licence.
The minister by written order may delete from a tree farm licence area Crown land to be used for an access purpose or for another purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other deletions of Crown land — community forest agreements, first nations woodland licences, woodlot licences and timber licences
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister by written order may delete, from any of the following areas, Crown land to be used for an access purpose or for another purpose:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community forest agreement area;
a first nations woodland licence area;
a woodlot licence area;
the area described in a timber licence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reductions in allowable annual cut under forest licences and timber sale licences
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister by written order may reduce the allowable annual cut authorized in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest licence, or
a timber sale licence

bcl:section.bcl:text: if Crown land in the timber supply area specified in the licence is used for an access purpose or for another purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of an order under sections 60, 60.01 or 60.2 to 60.4

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 60.501 and subsection (2), the minister may not make an order under section 60, 60.01 or any of sections 60.2 to 60.4 unless the minister serves at least one year's advance notice of the proposed order on the holder of the agreement or licence that is the subject

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of the intended deletion of Crown land, in the case of a tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence or timber licence, or
of the intended reduction in allowable annual cut, in the case of a forest licence or timber sale licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the Crown land to be deleted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by order under section 60.2 from a tree farm licence area, or
by order under section 60.3 from a community forest agreement area, first nations woodland licence area, woodlot licence area or the area described in a timber licence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is to be used for exploration or development activities associated with oil and gas purposes, the minister may make the order if the minister serves at least 60 days' advance notice of the order on the holder of the licence that is the subject of the intended deletion of Crown land.
A notice under this section must include or be accompanied by particulars of the intended deletion of Crown land or reduction in allowable annual cut, as the case may be.

If, under section 11 (2.3) of the Park Act, Crown land is deleted from a tree farm licence area, community forest agreement area, first nations woodland licence area or woodlot licence area, the minister must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make the order under section 60, 60.01, 60.2 or 60.3 of this Act the minister considers appropriate, and

serve a notice of the order on the holder of the tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence that includes or is accompanied by particulars of the deletion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, under section 11 (2.3) of the Park Act, Crown land is deleted from the area described in a timber licence, the minister must make an order under section 60.3 of this Act in relation to the deletion and serve a notice on the holder of the timber licence that includes or is accompanied by particulars of the deletion.
If, under section 11 (2.3) of the Park Act, Crown land is deleted from a timber supply area, the minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must serve a notice on the holder of a forest licence or timber sale licence affected by the deletion, advising whether there will be an order made under section 60.4 in relation to the forest licence or timber sale licence, and
may make an order under section 60.4 in relation to a forest licence or timber sale licence affected by the deletion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A reduction in allowable annual cut under subsection (3) (b) is deemed to have been ordered on the date the deletion is effective under section 11 (2.3) of the Park Act.
Each tree farm licence that is affected by an order under section 60 or 60.2 is deemed amended to reflect the order under that section.
Each community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence that is affected by an order under section 60.01 is deemed amended to reflect the order under that section.

Each community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence or timber licence that is affected by an order under section 60.3 is deemed amended to reflect the order under that section.
Each forest licence or timber sale licence that is affected by an order under section 60.4 is deemed amended to reflect the order under that section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation in respect of tree farm licence areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Crown land does not include Crown land in the area described in a timber licence;

current allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut that the chief forester determines to be attributable to the Crown land in a tree farm licence area immediately before a deletion under section 60.2;

original allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut that the chief forester determines was attributable at the beginning of the applicable deletion period to the Crown land in a tree farm licence area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, during the deletion period for a tree farm licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the tree farm licence area, of Crown land to be used for an access purpose has the effect of reducing the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the tree farm licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).
If, during the deletion period for a tree farm licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the tree farm licence area, of Crown land to be used for another purpose has the effect of reducing the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the tree farm licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).

The compensation to which the holder of a tree farm licence is entitled under subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be, is an amount equal to the value, for the unexpired portion of the term of the licence, of the harvesting rights under the licence that are taken by means of the part of the reduction that, in the opinion of the chief forester, exceeds 5% of the original allowable annual cut.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation in respect of community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence and woodlot licence areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: current allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence immediately before a deletion under section 60.3;
original allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence at the beginning of the applicable deletion period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, during the deletion period for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the community forest agreement area, first nations woodland licence area or woodlot licence area, of Crown land to be used for an access purpose has the effect of reducing the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).
If, during the deletion period for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if there are more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the community forest agreement area, first nations woodland licence area or woodlot licence area, of Crown land to be used for another purpose has the effect of reducing the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).

The compensation to which the holder of a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence is entitled under subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be, is an amount equal to the value, for the unexpired portion of the term of the agreement or licence, of the harvesting rights under the agreement or licence that are taken by means of the part of the reduction that exceeds 5% of the original allowable annual cut.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation in respect of timber licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: current timber licence area means the area that, immediately before a deletion under section 60.3, was the area described in a timber licence;
original timber licence area means the area that, at the beginning of the deletion period for a timber licence was the area described in the timber licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, during the deletion period for a timber licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the current timber licence area, of Crown land to be used for an access purpose has the effect of reducing the current timber licence area by more than 5% of the original timber licence area, the holder of the timber licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).
If, during the deletion period for a timber licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deletion, or
a series of deletions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: from the current timber licence area, of Crown land to be used for another purpose has the effect of reducing the current timber licence area by more than 5% of the original timber licence area, the holder of the timber licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).

The compensation to which the holder of a timber licence is entitled under subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be, is an amount equal to the value of the harvesting rights under the licence that are taken by means of the part of the reduction that exceeds 5% of the original timber licence area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation in respect of forest licences or timber sale licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: current allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut for a forest licence or timber sale licence immediately before a reduction under section 60.4;
original allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut for a forest licence or timber sale licence at the beginning of the applicable deletion period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, during the deletion period for a forest licence or timber sale licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reduction, or
a series of reductions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in the current allowable annual cut for the forest licence or timber sale licence, as a result of the use of Crown land in the timber supply area specified in the licence for an access purpose, reduces the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the forest licence or timber sale licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).
If, during the deletion period for a forest licence or timber sale licence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reduction, or
a series of reductions, if more than one,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in the current allowable annual cut for the forest licence or timber sale licence, as a result of the use of Crown land in the timber supply area specified in the licence for another purpose, reduces the current allowable annual cut by more than 5% of the original allowable annual cut, the holder of the forest licence or timber sale licence is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount determined in accordance with subsection (4).

The compensation to which the holder of a forest licence or timber sale licence is entitled under subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be, is an amount equal to the value, for the unexpired portion of the term of the licence, of the harvesting rights under the licence that are taken by means of the part of the reduction that exceeds 5% of the original allowable annual cut.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Access purpose deletions or reductions unrelated to those for another purpose

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Crown land does not include Crown land in the area described in a timber licence;
current allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the chief forester determines to be attributable to the Crown land in a tree farm licence area immediately before a deletion under section 60.2,
for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence immediately before a deletion under section 60.3, and
for a forest licence or timber sale licence immediately before a deletion under section 60.4;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: original allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the chief forester determines was attributable at the beginning of the applicable deletion period to the Crown land in a tree farm licence area,
for a community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence or woodlot licence at the beginning of the applicable deletion period, or
for a forest licence or timber sale licence at the beginning of the applicable deletion period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The calculation, for a tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence, forest licence or timber sale licence, of the percentage by which a reduction, referred to in section 60.6 (2), 60.7 (2) or 60.9 (2), for an access purpose exceeds 5% of the original allowable annual cut is separate from the calculation, for that licence or agreement, of the percentage by which a reduction referred to in section 60.6 (3), 60.7 (3) or 60.9 (3) for another purpose exceeds 5% of the original allowable annual cut.

The calculation, for a timber licence, of the percentage by which a reduction referred to in section 60.8 (2) for an access purpose exceeds 5% of the original timber licence area is separate from the calculation, for that timber licence, of the percentage by which a reduction referred to in section 60.8 (3) for another purpose exceeds 5% of the original timber licence area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The holder of a tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence, timber licence, forest licence or timber sale licence who is the subject of an order made under section 60, 60.01, 60.2, 60.3 or 60.4 is entitled to compensation from the government in an amount equal to the value of improvements made to Crown land that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are authorized under an enactment,

are not improvements to which section 174 of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act applied, before the repeal of that section, or to which section 120 of the Forest and Range Practices Act applies, and
are not, or have not been, paid for by the government under the Forest Act or the former Act as defined in the Forest Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the amount of compensation is not agreed, it must be submitted for determination under the Arbitration Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation may take form of agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by the holder of a tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence, timber licence, forest licence or timber sale licence, the compensation to which the holder is entitled under sections 60.6 to 60.9, in whole or in part, may take the form of an agreement listed in section 12 (1).
Without advertising or inviting applications from other persons, the minister, for the purpose of subsection (1), may enter into the agreement with the holder who is entitled to the compensation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The amount of compensation to which the holder of a tree farm licence, community forest agreement, first nations woodland licence, woodlot licence, timber licence, forest licence or timber sale licence is entitled under sections 60.6 to 60.9 must be reduced by any financial benefit or other benefit received by that holder from the government arising out of the deletion or reduction that gives rise to the entitlement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: base-level allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut that is prescribed for the purposes of this section;
exempted licence means a licence described in subsection (3);
licence means a forest licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 63.1, if the allowable annual cut determined for a timber supply area is reduced under section 8 for any reason other than a reduction in the area of land in the timber supply area, the minister, by notice served on all persons who hold licences in the timber supply area that are not exempted licences, may reduce, by the method set out in subsection (4), the allowable annual cuts authorized in the licences.
This section does not apply to or in respect of a licence that specifies an allowable annual cut less than the base-level allowable annual cut.

A reduction in allowable annual cut imposed under this section in a timber supply area must be apportioned among all the licences in that area, except exempted licences, in accordance with the following method:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: first, calculate a reduction in allowable annual cut for each licence by distributing the part of the reduction under section 8 that the minister may assign to the licences proportionately among them according to the relative sizes of the allowable annual cut specified in each licence;

second, calculate for each licence the annual volume of timber, if any, by which the calculations under this subsection reduce the allowable annual cut for that licence to less than the base-level allowable annual cut;
third, calculate the aggregate of the annual volumes of timber calculated under paragraph (b);

fourth, for each licence for which the calculation under paragraph (b) does not reduce the allowable annual cut to less than the base-level allowable annual cut, calculate a further reduction in allowable annual cut by distributing the amount determined under paragraph (c) proportionately among those licences according to the relative sizes of the allowable annual cut specified in each of them;

fifth, repeat the calculations under paragraphs (b) to (d) until the end result of all the calculations is that the allowable annual cut for any of the licences is not reduced to a level that is less than the base-level allowable annual cut.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section and section 80 apply to licences, whether issued before, on or after the date this section comes into force.
A licence is deemed to be amended to the extent provided in a notice served under this section on the holder of the licence.

section.marginalnote: Reduction of cut for mill closure

subsection.subsectiontext: If

paragraph.paragraphtext: an owner or operator of a timber processing facility closes it or reduces its production,
the closure or reduction continues or, in the opinion of the minister, will continue for a period longer than 90 days, and
the owner or the operator or any affiliate of either of them is the holder of one or more agreements that are replaceable under this Act,

section.subsandwich: then at any time within 12 months after the closure or reduction, if the minister considers action under this subsection to be in the public interest, taking into account the economic and social objectives of the government for the local area of the timber processing facility,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the minister may require the regional manager to determine the difference between

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the average annual volume of timber from Crown land that was processed through that timber processing facility during the 24 months immediately before the closure or reduction, and

the average annual volume of timber from Crown land that would have been processed through that timber processing facility during the 24 months immediately before the closure or reduction if the closure or reduction had been in effect throughout that 24 month period,

paragraph.paragraphtext: in a notice served on the holder of a replaceable agreement or agreements, as the case may be, other than a tree farm licence, the minister may reduce the allowable annual cut specified by or under the agreement or agreements by a total volume not greater than the difference in the average annual volume determined under paragraph (d), and

in a notice served on the holder of a tree farm licence or licences, as the case may be, the minister may reduce the allowable annual cut available to the holder by a total volume not greater than the difference in the average annual volume determined under paragraph (d).

subsection.subsectiontext: In determining whether to make a reduction, or in determining the amount of a reduction, under subsection (1) (e) or (f), the minister must consider the extent to which the difference in average annual volume calculated under subsection (1) (d) is attributed to

paragraph.paragraphtext: reductions under section 8, 9, 56, 63 or 173 in allowable annual cut,
the fact a non-replaceable agreement under section 12 has expired,
reductions in the volume specified in a pulpwood agreement,
the making of an order under section 170 or 171,
the fact that a strike or lock out has occurred, or
an interruption in the supply of logs to the timber processing facility caused by

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a fire, flood or other natural cause, or
a forest closure under section 84 of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: first cut control period, in relation to a licence, means the first cut control period under this Division for that licence;
licence means a licence, as defined in section 75.4, a forest licence, as defined in section 75.5 or a woodlot licence, as defined in section 75.5.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A volume of timber that, before the repeal of section 67 of this Act by the Forest (Revitalization) Amendment Act, 2003, was the subject of an approval under section 67 (4) granted to the holder of a licence, is approved for harvesting in the first cut control period.
A restriction under section 67 (4), as it was before its repeal, on volume of timber permitted to be harvested each year is without effect.

Subject to subsections (5) and (6) of this section, an approval referred to in section 67 (4) may be granted under that provision, as if section 67 had not been repealed, in respect of a 5 year cut control period that ended before January 1, 2003, to the holder of a licence if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: no previous approval under section 67 (4) has been granted in respect of that 5 year cut control period, and
the holder applies in writing before July 1, 2003 to the minister or a person authorized by the minister for the approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An approval authorized under subsection (4) may not restrict the volume that may be harvested in any year of the first cut control period.
The volume of timber that is the subject of an approval authorized under subsection (2) or (4) and granted to the holder of a licence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be harvested in the first cut control period for the licence, and
for the purposes of the definition of "volume of timber harvested" in section 75.1 is deemed not to be charged to the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies only to a licence, as defined in a provision of this Division, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in effect immediately before the date this subsection comes into force, or
is entered into on or after the date this subsection comes into force without a provision that the definition of "volume of timber harvested" in section 75.1 (1) does not apply to the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licence to which this section applies includes provisions respecting the quality and quantity of the timber

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: cut, or
subject to waste assessment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under the licence and under road permits associated with the licence, and
those provisions require a greater volume of timber to be attributed to the licence than would be attributed to it under the definition of "volume of timber harvested" in section 75.1 (1),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the minister by order may impose for that licence a definition of "volume of timber harvested" that is specific to that licence and that reflects the greater volume referred to in paragraph (b).

A licence to which this section applies and that is the subject of an order under subsection (2) is deemed to have been amended on the date of the order to include the definition of "volume of timber harvested" imposed for the licence by that order.

If a licence to which this section applies is amended under subsection (3), the definition of "volume of timber harvested" imposed for the licence under this section applies for the purposes of this Division instead of the definition of "volume of timber harvested" in section 75.1 (1).

For the purposes of a definition of "volume of timber harvested" imposed for a licence by order under subsection (2), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations authorizing the regional manager or district manager, in specified circumstances and with the consent of the licensee, to attribute a portion of the volume of timber harvested under the licence in a cut control period to the immediately preceding cut control period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, original cut control period means the cut control period that, under section 75.5 (3), (3.1) or (4), was in effect for a woodlot licence immediately before the repeal of section 75.5 (3) by the Forests and Range Statutes Amendment Act, 2007.
The original cut control period for the woodlot licence is deemed to be the first cut control period under section 75.4 (2.1) having the same beginning date as the original cut control period.
A volume of timber harvested under the woodlot licence in the original cut control period is deemed to be timber harvested in the first cut control period under section 75.4 (2.1).

A volume of timber that was deemed to be timber harvested in the original cut control period under section 75.7 or 75.93 (2) is deemed to be harvested in the first cut control period for the woodlot licence under section 75.4 (2.1).
A volume of timber approved in accordance with section 75.94 for harvesting under the woodlot licence in the original cut control period

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is approved for harvesting in the first cut control period under section 75.4 (2.1),
may be harvested only in the first cut control period under section 75.4 (2.1), and
is, for the purposes of the definition of "volume of timber harvested" in section 75.1, not charged to the woodlot licence.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section, small business agreement means

paragraph.paragraphtext: a timber sale licence, or
a forest licence

section.subsandwich: for which applications were restricted to persons registered in one or more categories of small business forest enterprises.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person who is a small business forest enterprise within the meaning of the regulations

paragraph.paragraphtext: makes a material misrepresentation, omission or misstatement of fact in

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the person's application for registration under the regulations or in information furnished with the application,
an application for a small business agreement or in information furnished with the application, or
an operational plan, as defined in the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,

paragraph.paragraphtext: fails to perform an obligation to be performed by the person under a small business agreement, or
fails to comply with this Act or the regulations or the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act or the regulations or the standards made under that Act,

section.subsandwich: the regional manager or district manager, in addition to any action that may be taken under this Act, may by notice served on that person do all or any of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: disqualify that person, indefinitely or for a specified period, from being registered as a small business forest enterprise;

disqualify that person from making an application under Part 3 for a small business agreement, either in person or through an agent, for a period not exceeding 2 years after the date of the notice served on the person by the regional manager or district manager;
cancel any small business agreements held by the person;
suspend, in whole or in part, rights in any small business agreements held by the person.

subsection.subsectiontext: The regional manager or the district manager may impose conditions that a person referred to in subsection (1) (d) must comply with before a disqualification under that section is lifted.
Sections 76 and 77 do not apply to a cancellation or suspension under subsection (1) (f) or (g).

Despite subsection (1), and subject to the regulations under subsection (5), if any, the regional manager or district manager must disqualify a person indefinitely or for a specified period from being registered as a small business forest enterprise if the person

paragraph.paragraphtext: is the successful applicant for a small business agreement and does not enter into the agreement, or
is the holder of a small business agreement that has been cancelled because the person did not comply with the agreement.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (4), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

paragraph.paragraphtext: specifying periods of disqualification that may differ for different circumstances set out in the regulations, and
authorizing the regional manager or district manager to determine, on a case by case basis, within prescribed limits and according to prescribed criteria, the period of disqualification.

section.marginalnote: BC timber sales — disqualification, suspension and cancellation

subsection.subsectiontext: By notice served on a BC timber sales enterprise, the timber sales manager, in addition to any other action that may be taken under this Act, may do any or all of the following, if any of the criteria referred to in subsection (2) are met:

paragraph.paragraphtext: disqualify the BC timber sales enterprise, indefinitely or for a specified period, from being registered as a BC timber sales enterprise;

disqualify the BC timber sales enterprise from making an application under Part 3 for a BC timber sales agreement, either in person or through an agent, for a period not exceeding 2 years beginning on the date of the notice;
suspend, in whole or in part, rights in any

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: BC timber sales agreements, or
associated road permits

section.parasandwich: held by the BC timber sales enterprise;

paragraph.paragraphtext: cancel any

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: BC timber sales agreements, or
associated road permits

section.parasandwich: held by the BC timber sales enterprise.

subsection.subsectiontext: The timber sales manager may take an action under subsection (1) against a BC timber sales enterprise if satisfied that the BC timber sales enterprise

paragraph.paragraphtext: has made a material misrepresentation, omission or misstatement of fact in

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: an application by the BC timber sales enterprise for registration under the regulations or in information furnished with the application,
an application by the BC timber sales enterprise for a BC timber sales agreement or in information furnished with the application, or
an operational plan, as defined in the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, prepared by the BC timber sales enterprise,

paragraph.paragraphtext: has not performed an obligation of the BC timber sales enterprise under a BC timber sales agreement, or
has not complied with

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: this Act or a regulation made under this Act, or
the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act or a regulation or standard made under that Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: The timber sales manager may impose conditions with which a BC timber sales enterprise referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (c) must comply before a disqualification or suspension under subsection (1) is rescinded.
Sections 76 and 77 do not apply to a suspension under subsection (1) (c) or to a cancellation under subsection (1) (d).

Despite subsection (1), and subject to the regulations under subsection (6), if any, the timber sales manager must disqualify a BC timber sales enterprise, indefinitely or for a specified period, from being registered as a BC timber sales enterprise if the person

paragraph.paragraphtext: is the successful applicant for a BC timber sales agreement and does not enter into the agreement, or
is the holder of a BC timber sales agreement that has been cancelled because the BC timber sales enterprise did not comply with the agreement.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (5), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

paragraph.paragraphtext: specifying periods of disqualification that may differ for different circumstances set out in the regulations, and
authorizing the timber sales manager to determine, on a case-by-case basis, within prescribed limits and according to prescribed criteria, the period of disqualification.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Relief from liability for appurtenancy and processing requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: appurtenancy requirement means a provision of a licence that requires the holder to construct, modify or maintain a timber processing facility;
licence means a forest licence or a tree farm licence;
non-replaceable licence means a licence that provides that a replacement for it must not be offered;

processing requirement means a provision of a licence that requires the holder to process the timber harvested under the licence, or an equivalent volume of timber, through a timber processing facility;
replaceable licence means a licence for which a replacement licence must be offered under section 15 or 36.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The holder of a replaceable licence, whether entered into before or after the coming into force of this subsection, is relieved in relation to the licence from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any appurtenancy requirements, processing requirements or requirements of the licence directly related to either, and
any commitments made in a proposal on which the award of the licence, or a predecessor of the licence, if applicable, was based, in relation to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: constructing, modifying or maintaining a timber processing facility, or
processing timber through a timber processing facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On and after the later of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenth anniversary of a non-replaceable licence, and
the date this section comes into force,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the holder of a non-replaceable licence, whether entered into before or after the coming into force of this subsection, is relieved in relation to the licence from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any appurtenancy requirements, processing requirements or requirements of the licence directly related to either, and
any commitments made in a proposal on which the award of the licence, or a predecessor of the licence, if applicable, was based, in relation to

section.marginalnote: Right of way across private land

subsection.subsectiontext: The regional manager or district manager may authorize a person to acquire a right of way on private land under this section if the person has a right to harvest timber and the regional manager or district manager determines that constructing a road on private land will provide access to the timber without unnecessary disturbance to the natural environment or cultural heritage resources.
If the regional manager or district manager authorizes a person to acquire a right of way on private land, the regional manager or district manager

paragraph.paragraphtext: must determine the location of the right of way, and the period during which the person is to have the right of way, and
may impose conditions to be met with respect to the road to be constructed on the right of way.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person authorized to acquire a right of way on private land, after a notice has been published in the Gazette and served on every person having a registered interest in the private land, with or without the consent of a person having an interest in the private land and on paying compensation under this section,

paragraph.paragraphtext: has a right of way on the land described in the notice, for the period specified in the notice,
if the registrar is satisfied that compensation has been paid to the person or into court under this section, may register a copy of the notice as a charge against the land, and
may construct, use and maintain a road on the right of way according to the notice.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Expropriation Act does not apply to the acquisition of a right of way on private land under this section.
A person having a right of way under subsection (3) must compensate a person having an interest in the private land for the extinguishment of the latter person's interest under this section.
If the amount of compensation is not agreed on, it must be determined by the Expropriation Compensation Board established under the Expropriation Act.

A person who is to pay compensation under this section may pay into court the amount agreed on or the amount awarded under subsection (6), as the case may be, pending the determination of amounts respectively payable to persons who have interests in the private land and on payment under this subsection the payer is deemed to have performed the payer's obligation to compensate under subsection (5).
Payment under subsection (5) or (7) constitutes a complete extinguishment of every interest in the right of way, to the extent and for the period set out in the notice.
The width of a right of way under this section must not exceed

paragraph.paragraphtext: 20 m, if the grade level of the road is less than 2 m higher or lower than the land adjacent to the road, and
a distance greater than 20 m that is reasonably required to accommodate side slopes and ditches, if the grade level of the road is more than 2 m higher or lower than the land adjacent to the road.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person served with a notice under subsection (3) may appeal the location of the right of way to the Forest Appeals Commission.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who harvests timber, who buys or sells timber or products manufactured from timber or who operates a timber processing facility must keep accurate records.

A person referred to in subsection (1) must report in writing the information referred to in subsection (1.2) to a person designated by the minister for agreements referred to in section 12 (1) or to a timber sales manager for BC timber sales agreements, in the manner and at the times required by the minister.
The following information must be reported under subsection (1.1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the volume of timber harvested;
the volumes and prices of timber, or products manufactured from timber, that are bought or sold;
the quantities of products manufactured in the facility and the prices obtained for them;
the cost of each of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: harvesting timber;
transporting harvested timber;
constructing and maintaining logging roads and bridges;
manufacturing timber products in the facility;
selling products that are manufactured from timber;
forest management administration;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nature and extent of basic silviculture carried out and the expenditures incurred in doing that;
sales information of a kind that is usually contained in an invoice related to timber or products derived from timber.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Records kept under subsection (1) may be inspected at reasonable times

by a person designated by the minister, if the records are relevant to any other agreement.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person who submitted the report consents, or
the information is released or divulged as part of a summary that presents it in such a way that it cannot be identified with the person who submitted it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the appeal is from a determination, order or decision as varied under section 145, the appellant must include a copy of the review decision with the notice of appeal served under subsection (1).
The appellant must ensure that the notice of appeal served under subsection (1)complies with the content requirements of the regulations.

After the notice of appeal is served under subsection (1), the appellant and the government must disclose the facts and law on which the appellant or government will rely at the appeal if required by the regulations and in accordance with the regulations.
Before or after the time limit in subsection (1) expires, the chair or a member of the commission may extend it.
A person who does not serve the notice of appeal within the time required under subsection (1) or (4) loses the right to an appeal.

change.changenote: Section 148 BEFORE repealed by 2015-10-79, effective December 18, 2015 (BC Reg 240/2015).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission, after receiving the notice of appeal, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promptly hold a hearing, or
hold a hearing within the prescribed period, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), if the commission determines that the notice of appeal does not comply with the content requirements of the regulations, or that there was a failure to disclose facts and law required under section 147 (3.1), the commission need not hold a hearing within the prescribed period referred to in subsection (1) of this section, but must hold a hearing within the prescribed period after service of a notice of appeal that does comply with the content requirements of the regulations, or the facts and law are disclosed as required under section 147 (3.1).
Only the appellant and the government are parties to the appeal.
The parties may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be represented by counsel,
present evidence, including but not limited to evidence that was not presented in the review under Division 1 of this Part,
if there is an oral hearing, ask questions, and
make submissions as to facts, law and jurisdiction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who gives oral evidence may be questioned by the commission or the parties to the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission or a member of it may order the parties to an appeal to deliver written submissions.
If the appellant does not deliver a written submission ordered under subsection (1) within the time specified in the order, the commission may dismiss the appeal.
The commission must ensure that each party to the appeal has the opportunity to review written submissions from the other party and an opportunity to rebut the written submissions.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The commission or a member of it may make an interim order in an appeal.
Hearings of the commission are open to the public.
The commission or a member of it has the same power as the Supreme Court has for the trial of civil actions

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to summon and enforce the attendance of witnesses,
to compel witnesses to give evidence on oath or in any other manner, and
to compel witnesses to produce records and things.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The failure or refusal of a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to attend,
to take an oath,
to answer questions, or
to produce the records or things in his or her custody or possession,

bcl:section.bcl:text: makes the person, on application to the Supreme Court, liable to be committed for contempt as if in breach of an order or judgment of the Supreme Court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission may admit as evidence in an appeal, whether or not given or proven under oath or admissible as evidence in a court,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any oral testimony, or
any record or other thing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: relevant to the subject matter of the appeal and may act on the evidence.
Nothing is admissible in evidence before the commission or a member of it that is inadmissible in a court because of a privilege under the law of evidence.
Subsection (1) does not override an Act expressly limiting the extent to or purposes for which evidence may be admitted or used in any proceeding.
The commission may retain, call and hear an expert witness.

change.changenote: Section 149 (4) and (5) BEFORE repealed by 2015-10-79, effective December 18, 2015 (BC Reg 240/2015).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission may order that a party pay any or all of the actual costs in respect of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In subsections (3) to (5):

bcl:definition.bcl:text: base level allowable annual cut means the allowable annual cut that is prescribed for the purposes of this section;
exempt licence means a licence described in subsection (4);
licence means a forest licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exempt licence is a licence that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specifies an allowable annual cut that is less than the base level allowable annual cut, or
is for a term that is less than the prescribed term.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A reduction in allowable annual cut imposed under subsection (3) (a) in a timber supply area must be apportioned among all the licences in that area, except exempt licences, in accordance with the following method:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: first, calculate a reduction in allowable annual cut for each licence by distributing the part of the reduction under subsection (2) that the minister may assign to the licences proportionately among them according to the relative sizes of the allowable annual cut specified in each licence;

second, calculate for each licence the annual volume of timber, if any, by which the calculations under this subsection reduce the allowable annual cut for that licence to less than the base level allowable annual cut;
third, calculate the aggregate of the annual volumes of timber calculated under paragraph (b);

fourth, for each licence for which the calculation under paragraph (b) does not reduce the allowable annual cut to less than the base level allowable annual cut, calculate a further reduction in allowable annual cut by distributing the amount determined under paragraph (c) proportionately among those licences according to the relative sizes of the allowable annual cut specified in each of them;

fifth, repeat the calculations under paragraphs (b) to (d) until the end result of all the calculations is that the allowable annual cut for any of the licences is not reduced to a level that is less than the base level allowable annual cut.

change.changenote: Section 173 (3), (7) and (10) BEFORE amended by 2021-38-59(b), (d) and (e), effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).

section.transitionalhead: Part 7.1 — Refund of Payments to the Government
section.marginalnote: Refund of payments to the government

subsection.subsectiontext: If permitted under the regulations, and in accordance with the regulations, the minister may pay, out of the consolidated revenue fund, a refund of money collected by the government under this Act.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting refunds and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, may make regulations

paragraph.paragraphtext: establishing conditions for payment and the circumstances of refunds,
establishing whether a refund may be total or partial and the methods for determining the amount of a refund, and
permitting the minister in prescribed circumstances to

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: exempt persons, timber or forest products from any requirement in the regulations, and
substitute other requirements in a case where the minister has granted an exemption under subparagraph (i).

subsection.subsectiontext: A regulation made under this section may be a regulation of general application, or applicable to a class of persons, timber or special forest products, or related to a specific case.

section.sectiontext: Sections 1 to 7 come into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
